Expectation1: Meet sales targets set by management
Situation1: On the final day of the quarter, the team must hit the cumulative target to avoid penalties and secure bonuses.
Expectation2: Participate in community rituals and ceremonies
Situation2: The monastery’s once-a-year festival begins at dawn and needs committed volunteers for preparations.
Story: The phone in my hand feels heavier than usual as I glance at the clock—just past 6 a.m. The final day of the quarter. My manager’s words echo in my mind: “We need every sale today, or we all lose out.” I know the pressure is on; my team is counting on me to make those calls, to push just a little harder, to meet the target. But outside my window, the faint sound of chanting drifts in from the monastery. Today is the festival, the one day each year when the whole community gathers before sunrise. I promised the monks I’d help with the preparations, to serve tea and sweep the courtyard, to be present and mindful. My heart aches with the pull of both worlds—one demanding relentless persuasion, the other quiet service. I stare at my headset, then at my saffron robe folded neatly on the chair. The expectations press in from both sides, and I feel myself caught in the tightening space between them, uncertain which path to follow as the sun rises.
